analytic.title: &title;

div.p: Algernon Charles Swinburne (1837-1909) wrote prolifically as a dramatist, novelist, and critic, though he is best known for his poetry. His early verse dramas, The Queen Mother (1860), Rosamond (1860), and Atalanta in Calydon (1865), did not receive much public or critical attention upon their initial publication, however.1 It was not until the publication of his Poems and Ballads (1866) that he achieved significant fame as a poet.2 The collection, along with his other works, dealt with themes which often shocked his contemporary readers, including an endorsement of republican politics; a rejection of Christianity; emphasis on romantic and sexual feeling; and a preoccupation with sadism, masochism, and flagellation.

As a result of his increasingly ill health and struggles with alcoholism, Swinburne put himself under the guardianship of a friend and legal advisor. His health improved, but he lived the final years of his life in comparative isolation and his later works lapsed into relative obscurity. He died of influenza in 1909 at the age of seventy-two. Although he was one of the most celebrated poets of his day, Swinburne and his works have received relatively little scholarly attention. Jerome McGann and Charles L. Sligh attribute this critical oversight to the fact that “[n]either Swinburne nor his writings are normal or ordinary.”3

This enumerative bibliography is comprised of secondary sources on Swinburne published from 1980 to 2010. The works which have been included were selected from the Cumulative Bibliography of Victorian Studies, 1970-2000, The Victorian Database online 2000-2004 and 2005-2009, the Victorian Poetry publication “Guide to the Year's Work in Victorian Poetry,” Year’s Work in English Studies (see “Works Cited”), along with searches of the MLA International Bibliography Database, ABELL, the Victorian Poetry archive, Project Muse, and JSTOR. Works in languages other than English and dissertation theses have been excluded. The purpose of this bibliography is to supplement Kirk H. Beetz’s Algernon Charles Swinburne: A Bibliography of Secondary Works, 1861-1980 (see 1982A1).

Sources are listed chronologically and divided into four sections within each year: books, chapters/essays in books, articles in periodicals, and digital projects and editions. Within each section entries are listed alphabetically by author.

note.bibl: Rooksby, Rikky. “Swinburne, Algernon Charles (1837-1909),” Oxford Dictionary of National Biography, Oxford UP, 2004; online edn, May 2009. .
